Welcome to Top10Archive! With popular shows
like "The Last Man On Earth" buzzing the media,

14.text:
it sometimes makes you think what life would
be like if.. you were the last person on Earth.

21.text:
From a Virus like the FOX show scripted, to
possible Earth-shattering asteroids, we're

26.text:
going to count down our picks for the 10 possible
Natural Apocalyptic Events.

31.text:
10. Pole Shifts
This is the least likely of our possible apocalyptic

37.text:
events since the reversal of the planet's
magnetic field has happened before in history;

42.text:
although, we aren't exactly "prepared" for
this type of disaster. It is speculated that

47.text:
during the next pole shift there will be a
200-year span where our planet's magnetic

52.text:
shield will be neutralized, allowing the sun's
solar blasts to strip away our atmosphere.

57.text:
Thankfully, that span is not long enough to
significantly reduce the atmosphere for life

62.text:
to die out, but does have other serious implications
such as increased risk of skin cancer, disruption

69.text:
to computers and navigational systems, and
can lead to fires and possible ecological

74.text:
disruptions. Organisms that use magnetoreception
to navigate, such as birds, bees and bacteria,

80.text:
might be disrupted, but is highly unlikely
due to species that went through the last

85.text:
pole flip are still around.
9. Climate Change - Global Warming

91.text:
Several different scenarios can lead to devastating
climate change where humanity is crippled

95.text:
or wiped out, but we are going to focus on
the cascading effects of global warming, granted

100.text:
in a very concise nutshell. Designated as
"non-linear" climate shifts, "singularities",

106.text:
or "tipping points" by scientists, experts
are discovering indicators of possible catastrophes

112.text:
as we speak. Melting glaciers are disrupting
local species of plant life and animals alike,

118.text:
as well as the North Atlantic Current, which,
if disrupted could make the Euro-Atlantic

122.text:
climate colder and more storm prone. As permafrost
melts, methane is released, a potent greenhouse

129.text:
gas, which in turn can affect marine plant
life due to higher temperatures and acidity

133.text:
caused by the absorption of excess carbon
dioxide from the atmosphere. Such reefs make

138.text:
up less than 1% of the Earth's surface, but
houses 25% of all marine life, which is essential

145.text:
for both the ecosystem of wildlife and people.
8. Pandemic

151.text:
A pandemic is a worldwide spread of a virus.
Often times, infecting animals first, then

156.text:
transferring to humans, but this is not always
the case. In 1918, a flu pandemic killed nearly

162.text:
100 million people, and right now, HIV infects
about 40 million people, and AIDS has caused

169.text:
more than 25 million deaths. Some viruses,
like Ebola, are too lethal, killing their

175.text:
hosts before it can spread while other viruses
spread very quickly but are cured before it

180.text:
can kill the host. How long before a virus
strand evolves to contain the right combination

185.text:
of both? In a pandemic, borders will be closed
and travel restricted to delay the virus onslaught,

191.text:
medical supplies, and medical personnel would
be in short supply, and even with mitigation

196.text:
death rates may be high. Without a cure, this
possible apocalyptic event could wipe humanity

206.text:
Some scientists postulate that there may be
a thin disk of dark matter running horizontally

211.text:
through our Milky Way galaxy and that our
solar system, which moves around the galactic

216.text:
center about every 250 million years, may
occasionally bob up and down through it in

221.text:
a weaving motion that lasts about 30 million
years. These scientists also note that this

227.text:
pattern of Earth's motion through the galactic
disk seems to correlate with mass extinctions.

232.text:
As the Earth passed through this disk of dark
matter, it would also absorb these particles

238.text:
which could lead to internal heating, volcanism,
tectonic upheavals, changes in sea level and

244.text:
climate, or even change the Earth's magnetic
field, all of which are thought to contribute

249.text:
to extinctions. Some have even theorized that
when our system goes through the dark matter

254.text:
disc, it can dislodge distant objects, sending
them in our direction.

259.text:
6. Solar Storms
Solar Storms are triggered when flares, sunspots,

265.text:
coronal mass ejections or any eruption of
mass and energy from the Sun tears into the

270.text:
earth's magnetic field. It then operates much
like a man-made electromagnetic pulse weapon,

276.text:
where the solar energetic particles strike
the Earth with a force that ionizes the atmosphere,

281.text:
creating a vast cloud of energetic electrons
that bounce around inside the atmosphere,

286.text:
destroying electronics and fusing conductive
wires everywhere. This would most likely take

292.text:
out a few satellites in orbit as well as cripple
our communication system, but many unforeseen

297.text:
problems could trickle down. Vital services
like transportation and sanitation would shut

302.text:
down, and the loss of power would plunge the
planet into darkness. But the most worrying

307.text:
aspects of this scenario are most governments
have not shielded vital equipment for such

312.text:
an event and that a solar storm could reach
us in as little as 12 hours.

318.text:
5. Gamma Ray Burst
It is believed that gamma-ray bursts are produced

323.text:
when a massive star goes supernova and collapses
into a neutron star or black hole. From here,

330.text:
the prevailing theory is that an intense beam
of gamma radiation that lasts from mere milliseconds

336.text:
to several minutes shoots like a beam from
its polar regions. Capable of discharging

341.text:
the same energy our sun releases in its entire
10 billion year lifetime in just a few seconds,

347.text:
it could easily devastate Earth if close enough
and aimed precisely in our direction. As this

353.text:
beam travels at the speed of light, we wouldn't
know it was going on until it was already

358.text:
underway and we would have no defense against
it. Much of the Earth's atmosphere would be

361.text:
burnt off and in the end, the Earth would
likely be void of life.

365.text:
4. Super Volcano
There are six well-known super volcanos, Aira

370.text:
in Japan, Taupo in New Zealand, Lake Toba
in Indonesia, and Yellowstone, Long Valley,

375.text:
and Valles Caldera in the United States, with
others around the globe that have yet to be

380.text:
discovered. If one of these natural death
machines ever erupted, it would erase virtually

385.text:
all life in a radius of hundreds of miles
from the site, and entire continental regions

390.text:
further out would be buried meters deep in
ash. The same ash would block out the sun,

395.text:
affecting weather and farming in the region.
Furthermore, it could easily trigger an ice

400.text:
age that would last hundreds or thousands
of years. Of the natural disasters on our

405.text:
list, this is one of the most likely scenarios;
Yellowstone erupts in 600,000 to 700,000-year

411.text:
cycles, the last one being 640,000 years ago,
meaning, it is due for an eruption at any

418.text:
given time.
3. Rogue Black Holes, Planets or Suns

423.text:
Hundreds of "rogue" black holes may dwell
in the Milky Way. During mergers between galaxies,

428.text:
one of two possible outcomes can occur. The
dominant black hole consumes the other, or,

433.text:
the black hole is ejected from the region,
which often then gains speed and travels through

438.text:
the vastness of space in solitude. The same
holds true for "rogue" suns and planets in

443.text:
their respective neighborhoods, except planets
don't merge, they collide. Granted that the

449.text:
odds of one of these elements hurdling through
space directly at Earth are astronomically

454.text:
small, each could have an annihilating wake
of destruction within their paths. To make

459.text:
things slightly worse, each in their own regard
is difficult to detect within the background

464.text:
of space using our current level of technology.
2. Asteroids

470.text:
Made famous as the culprit in the destruction
of the dinosaurs, then romanticized by the

475.text:
book and film industry, an asteroid impact
is probably the most recognized apocalyptic

481.text:
event in the world, except perhaps a zombie
outbreak. An asteroid impacting Earth would

486.text:
release a tremendous amount of energy equivalent
to its relative size and velocity. The one

491.text:
that wiped out the dinosaurs was estimated
to be seven to eight miles long and upheaved

496.text:
a dust plume that spread across the planet
while forests and plant life caught ablaze

500.text:
and spread. Today that impact would have killed
millions, leaving those who didn't perish

506.text:
rummaging for resources. To completely obliterate
the human race, though, an estimated 60-mile

512.text:
wide asteroid would have to collide with our
world.

515.text:
1. Unknown Unknowns
Similar to the Black Swan Theory, which is

520.text:
a metaphor that describes an event that is
unprecedented and unexpected, difficult to

525.text:
predict, and often inappropriately rationalized
after the fact. This takes our number one

531.text:
spot and may be the worst apocalyptic event
as it is yet to be discovered. What lurks

536.text:
in the vastness of space? What terrible concept
have we not conceived of or yet witnessed

542.text:
that may still be out there? It is the unknown
apocalyptic scenarios that still linger out

548.text:
of our reach that could be the worst humanity
will ever come across.
